title: How-To Guide: Understanding ETFs & Other Pooled Investment Vehicles

content.text: Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs) are pooled investment vehicles that let investors buy a basket of assets (stocks, bonds, commodities) in one trade.
Like stocks, ETFs trade on exchanges throughout the day.

content.title: Benefits
items: Diversification → reduces the risk of relying on a single company/asset.
Cost efficiency → typically lower fees than actively managed funds.
Liquidity → can buy and sell anytime during trading hours at real-time prices.

content.heading: How ETFs Compare to Other Funds Types

items: Actively Managed → Managers decide which assets to buy/sell.
Trading: Bought or sold only at the end of the trading day.
Investor Impact: If many investors withdraw, the fund’s Assets Under Management (AUM) shrink, reducing the manager’s fee income.
Costs: Tend to have higher fees due to research and trading.
Structure: Fixed number of shares issued → investors buy/sell on exchanges like stocks.
Manager Insulation: Investor dissatisfaction doesn’t force withdrawals → the manager’s AUM remains steady.
Trading: Shares may trade at a premium or discount to NAV depending on demand. (NAV → Net Asset Value)
Blends traits of both: Like CEFs → traded on exchanges at real-time prices; Like mutual funds → diversified, pooled structure.
Popularity: Often passively managed (track an index), but actively managed ETFs exist too.
Active funds (mutual funds, some ETFs) → higher fees due to research, trading, and decision-making.

content.text: Cover customer service, recordkeeping, account statements, etc.
ETFs & CEFs: Bought/sold via brokers. May involve commissions or spreads. Open-End Mutual Funds: Bought/sold directly from the fund company at NAV (no intraday trading).

Funds regularly distribute income (interest & dividends) and capital gains. You may owe taxes on these distributions, even if you reinvest them. ETFs are usually more tax-efficient than mutual funds because of their unique 'in-kind redemption' process.

items: ETFs = flexible, low-cost, diversified → great for beginners.
Mutual funds = more managed, but higher costs.
Closed-end funds = stable for managers, but prices may differ from true value.
Always consider fees + taxes before investing.
